intro.description:
Ok, let's create our first scenario.
Note: 'Scenario' is the term used to describe the collection of data that is collated in order for SATC to produce an optimal 'Solution'.

item.title: Browse to the sensor data
item.description:
We're going to use all of the ownship sensor data to create our scenario.
So, open the Outline View, then open the Track:OWNSHIP. The ownship track has a Sensors (1 items) object. Open this and you will see the single block of sensor data, titled Sensor:Plain (11 items).

item.title: Select a block of sensor cuts
item.description: Ok, we've found the sensor data. Now right-click on this item (Sensor:Plain (11 items)), and select Semi Auto TMA / Create new solution from these bearings

item.title: Create scenario based upon cuts
item.description:
You should see that there is now a new item in the Outline View. It has been given the name 121213.14, that is the DTG of the first item in the bearing data.
You will also see that the Maintain Contributions view has opened - you will use this to create and manage your scenario data. If you didn't read about the SATC user interface via the help page earlier on, please read it now using the Click to perform link provided below.

item.title: Change scenario name
item.description: As stated earlier, the scenario is currently named 121213.14. This automatic naming is convenient in that it stops you (the analyst) having to make one up on the spur of the moment, but we're going to rename it to avoid confusion later on. So, select the new scenario in the Outline View, and now use the Properties view to change its Name value to Single Leg.

item.title: Finding the Properties view
item.description: Hey, if you're unable to change the name becase you can't find the Properties view, just select it from Debrief's Window / Show View menu. Then select the scenario once again in the Outline View.

item.title: Understand the contributions window
item.description: From the Maintain Contributions view you will see that there is a single item listed in the Analyst Contributions. This is the bearing data that will be used to inform all of the subsequent contributions.

item.title: Viewing the bearing measurement contributions
item.description:
Let's learn more about the Bearing Measurement Contribution. This contribution is the set of bearings that represent the unknown target track. You will see that the contribution has an estimate value of +/- 3 degs. This means the algorithm will only offer solutions that are within 3 degrees of these bearing measurements.
You can view these measurements. First, select the Single Leg in the Outline View. Then, in the Properties Window, tick the ShowLocationConstraints item.
A set of "pie-slices" will now appear on the plot, showing the 3 degree allowable error on each bearing measurement. If you expand the Bearing Measurement - Bearing Data contribution in the Maintain Contributions view, you will see that it is possible to change the error value on this bearing data by moving the slider. As you move the slider you will see the pie slices expand and contract.
Note: the Preferences area of the Maintain Contributions view includes the Auto-Recalc of Constraints two-state button. This button is normally depressed. But, if you have a complex scenario that takes some time to update, you may wish to un-check this button. The screen will no longer be refreshed as you are interactively adjusting any contributions.

item.title: Get ready to specify a target leg
item.description:
Note that in this sample data, we have a maximum range value for the bearings, of 12kyds. In the absence of a range estimate they will be drawn out to 30 kyds.
Also, before we continue, we need to reset Debrief to a predictable state, so please restore the Bearing Measurement analyst contribution to 3 degrees, and also clear the ShowLocationConstraints checkbox for in the Properties View for the Single Leg scenario.

item.title: Specify a target leg
item.description:
Your deep, deep, analysis skills have led you to believe that all of these cuts relate to a single leg of target data - in other words, the target maintains course and speed through the period of interest.
That information is useful to the TMA algorithms. Provide this information to the TMA algorithm by right-clicking once again on the Sensor:Plain (11 items) item in the Outline View, then browse down the menu to Semi Auto TMA, then Add to Single Leg. From the menu that appears, select New Straight Leg for period covered by [sensor cuts]. From the dialog that opens, name the contribution as Leg limits

item.title: Understand the contributions
item.description: So, now there are two contributions: one which provides a set of bearings through which a solution must travel, and another which indicates that the target will have travelled on a single course and speed throughout the engagement. The sharp-witted amongst you will have noticed that our two ownship turns have provided a valuable change in bearing rate - just the thing a TMA algorithm wants.
